Award.AwardTitle: Energetic Neutrinos from the Sun and the Earth and the Granularity of the Dark Matter Distribution
Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the most compelling indications for new physics beyond the Standard Model is the apparent existence of dark matter. Unfortunately, however, very little is known about the nature of dark matter. One important way of possibly detecting dark matter is through neutrino signals coming from the Sun and the Earth. However, it was recently pointed out by the PI and collaborators that the presence of non-trivial structure in the distribution of dark matter can result in elevated neutrino signals. In this project, Professor Koushiappas aims to establish a research program that will more fully assess the implications of granularity of the phase space distribution function of dark matter on the energetic neutrino signal from the Sun and the Earth. Thus, the main goal of this proposal is to determine how structure in the distribution of dark matter and its velocity acts on the expected neutrino signal.

This project is also envisioned to have several broader impacts. Beyond the intellectual aspects of increasing our understanding of dark matter, the graduate student participating in this research will acquire unique skills and a breadth of experience that will prepare her/him well for a future research career. The products of this research will also be incorporated into the regular outreach activities at Brown University and Ladd Observatory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project led to the following interesting results: 1) The annihilation cross section of dark matter particles with masses less than few tens of GeV is lower than the benchmark thermal annihilation cross section, 2) developed a comprehensive and detailed formalism on how one can estimate the contribution of pulsars to the gamma-ray background, 3) developed the theory for the computation of the space-time correlation function of astro-particle physics events, 4) searched for the presence of an annihilation line from dwarf spheroidal galaxies and 5) computed the dark matter halo-to-halo variance in dark matter substructure and its implications to strongly gravitationally lensed systems. 

These results have important implications to many branches of physics. Results 1) and 4) are important in particle physics and in the search for dark matter (the matter that constitutes about 26% of the energy density of the universe (normal matter is only about 4%)). This work showed that low-mass weakly interacting particles cannot be the dark matter under the simplest assumptions, in other words something more complex than what has been assumed in the last 30 years must be the solution. Results 2) and 3) have numerous applications in many experimental studies, and set the framework over which time-domain analysis can be performed in large data sets. Finally, result 5) probes the structure of dark matter halos as well as the structure of the universe.
